results.title: Right Through the Shearing Time
results.creator_credit: John Maybe, Trevor Stockley and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
This film features sheep shearing at Moree and Yass, in New South Wales, and provides extensive information about this distinctive Australian industry. It also shows the life of the seasonal workers who are employed in this rural activity.

results.title: Brush with royalty
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
A group of artists from Broken Hill prepare for an exhibition of their work in London. Artists include Pro Hart and Jack Absalom, and all use the countryside around Broken Hill as their source of inspiration. This film is recommended for students in Years 9-12.

results.title: Be it ever so humble
results.creator_credit: Ron Iddon, John Sparkes and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Shot in Queensland, this film examines the development in styles of houses in Australia, from the slab hut to the contemporary brick house. Suitable for Upper Secondary-Tertiary level students.

results.title: Two faces of Gove
results.creator_credit: Ron Iddon, John Sparkes and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Looks at the situation at Gove, after the 1971 Land Rights Case, in which Naalco were given clear title to the lease. Considers the effect of the decision on the people of Yirrakala. Construction workers talk about their attitudes and relations with the Aborigines. Shows social life and bauxite mining procedures.

results.title: Quiet challenge
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Concerned about Australia’s lack of success in international sports aviation events, ex-businessman Bill Reilly has established a school for advanced glider-pilot training at Tokamore, N.S.W. Resident championship Ingo Reuner, aeronautical pilot and Bert Persson, engineer, display their skills and explain the fascination that gliding holds for them.

results.title: The People v the 'roo
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
The kangaroo is observed in its own environment, and the people who are most likely to affect its future are interviewed: the grazier, the wildlife officer, the shooter and the pet food supplier.

results.title: Orbost v Orbost
results.creator_credit: David Wood, John Sparkes and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Orbost in Victoria is a fairly normal country town, but it has one outstanding feature - two football clubs. Every winter, football becomes the focal point in the lives of most of the local people, and it provides a good deal of their social life. In this film the two local teams compete in the district final, and football fever reaches its highest pitch.

results.title: Mulga Bill's Bicycle Band
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Mulga Bill’s Bicycle Band, a group of musicians from Melbourne, play adaptations of English and Irish folk music. This episode of A Big Country follows the band as they rescue their music from the abstractions of television studios and return it to the living ambience of country halls and hotels.

results.title: The Man from Tocumwal
results.creator_credit: Ken Dyer, John Sparkes and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
A study of Fred James, managing director of the textile firm Cleckheaton, and new owner of the famous Falkiner Merino Stud at Congaro, N.S.W. James explains his interest in the wool industry, criticises the Australian Wool Board and discusses wool’s marketing and promotional problems. Also shows his modern textile mill at Shepparton, Victoria.
